content.text: PHP OOP - Inheritance
PHP - What is Inheritance?
Inheritance in OOP = When a class derives from another class.
content.html: Inheritance in OOP = When a class derives from another class.

content.text: The child class will inherit all the public and protected properties and methods from the parent class. In addition, it can have its own properties and methods.
content.html: The child class will inherit all the public and protected properties and methods from the parent class. In addition, it can have its own properties and methods.

content.text: An inherited class is defined by using the extends keyword.
content.html: An inherited class is defined by using the extends keyword.

content.text: Let's look at an example:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<?phpclass Fruit {  public 
    $name;  public $color;  public 
    function __construct($name, $color) {    $this->name = $name;    $this->color = $color;
      }  
    public function intro() {    echo "The fruit is {$this->name} 
    and the color is {$this->color}.";
      }}// Strawberry is inherited from Fruitclass 
    Strawberry extends Fruit {  public 
    function message() {    echo "Am I a fruit or a 
    berry? ";
      }}$strawberry = new Strawberry("Strawberry", "red");$strawberry->message();$strawberry->intro();
    ?>

"The fruit is {$this->name} 
    and the color is {$this->color}."

"Am I a fruit or a 
    berry? "

content.code:
<?phpclass Fruit {  public 
$name;  public $color;  public
function __construct($name, $color) {    $this->name = $name;    $this->color = $color;
}
public function intro() {    echo "The fruit is {$this->name}
and the color is {$this->color}.";
}}// Strawberry is inherited from Fruitclass
Strawberry extends Fruit {  public
function message() {    echo "Am I a fruit or a
berry? ";
}}$strawberry = new Strawberry("Strawberry", "red");$strawberry->message();$strawberry->intro();
?>

syntax_highlighting.text:
<?phpclass Fruit {  public 
    $name;  public $color;  public 
 function __construct($name, $color) {    $this->name = $name;    $this->color = $color;
   }  
 public function intro() {    echo "The fruit is {$this->name} 
    and the color is {$this->color}.";
   }}// Strawberry is inherited from Fruitclass 
    Strawberry extends Fruit {  public 
 function message() {    echo "Am I a fruit or a 
    berry? ";
   }}$strawberry = new Strawberry("Strawberry", "red");$strawberry->message();$strawberry->intro();
 ?>

content.code_html:
<?php
class Fruit {
  public $name;
  public $color;
  public function __construct($name, $color) {
    $this->name = $name;
    $this->color = $color;
  }
  public function intro() {
    echo "The fruit is {$this->name} and the color is {$this->color}.";
  }
}

// Strawberry is inherited from Fruit
class Strawberry extends Fruit {
  public function message() {
    echo "Am I a fruit or a berry? ";
  }
}
$strawberry = new Strawberry("Strawberry", "red");
$strawberry->message();
$strawberry->intro();
?>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
<?phpclass Fruit {  public 
    $name;  public $color;  public 
    function __construct($name, $color) {    $this->name = $name;    $this->color = $color;
      }  
    public function intro() {    echo "The fruit is {$this->name} 
    and the color is {$this->color}.";
      }}// Strawberry is inherited from Fruitclass 
    Strawberry extends Fruit {  public 
    function message() {    echo "Am I a fruit or a 
    berry? ";
      }}$strawberry = new Strawberry("Strawberry", "red");$strawberry->message();$strawberry->intro();
    ?>

"The fruit is {$this->name} 
    and the color is {$this->color}."

"Am I a fruit or a 
    berry? "

content.text: Example Explained
The Strawberry class is inherited from the Fruit class.
content.html: The Strawberry class is inherited from the Fruit class.

content.text: This means that the Strawberry class can use the public $name and $color properties as well as the public __construct() and intro() methods from the Fruit class because of inheritance.
content.html: This means that the Strawberry class can use the public $name and $color properties as well as the public __construct() and intro() methods from the Fruit class because of inheritance.

content.text: The Strawberry class also has its own method: message().
content.html: The Strawberry class also has its own method: message().

content.text: PHP - Inheritance and the Protected Access Modifier
In the previous chapter we learned that protected properties or methods can be accessed within the class and by classes derived from that class. What does that mean?
content.html: In the previous chapter we learned that protected properties or methods can be accessed within the class and by classes derived from that class. What does that mean?

content.text: Let's look at an example:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<?phpclass Fruit {  public 
    $name;  public $color;  public 
    function __construct($name, $color) {    $this->name = $name;    $this->color = $color;
      }  
    protected function intro() {    echo "The fruit is {$this->name} 
    and the color is {$this->color}.";
      }}class 
    Strawberry extends Fruit {  public 
    function message() {    echo "Am I a fruit or a 
    berry? ";
      }}// Try to call all three methods from outside class$strawberry = new Strawberry("Strawberry", "red");  
    // OK. __construct() is public$strawberry->message(); // OK. message() 
    is public$strawberry->intro(); // ERROR. intro() 
    is protected
    ?>

"The fruit is {$this->name} 
    and the color is {$this->color}."

"Am I a fruit or a 
    berry? "
// Try to call all three methods from outside class

content.code:
<?phpclass Fruit {  public 
$name;  public $color;  public
function __construct($name, $color) {    $this->name = $name;    $this->color = $color;
}
protected function intro() {    echo "The fruit is {$this->name}
and the color is {$this->color}.";
}}class
Strawberry extends Fruit {  public
function message() {    echo "Am I a fruit or a
berry? ";
}}// Try to call all three methods from outside class$strawberry = new Strawberry("Strawberry", "red");
// OK. __construct() is public$strawberry->message(); // OK. message()
is public$strawberry->intro(); // ERROR. intro()
is protected
?>

 // OK. __construct() is public$strawberry->message(); // OK. message()

 ?>

// Try to call all three methods from outside class

content.code_html:
<?php
class Fruit {
  public $name;
  public $color;
  public function __construct($name, $color) {
    $this->name = $name;
    $this->color = $color;
  }
  protected function intro() {
    echo "The fruit is {$this->name} and the color is {$this->color}.";
  }
}

class Strawberry extends Fruit {
  public function message() {
    echo "Am I a fruit or a berry? ";
  }
}

// Try to call all three methods from outside class
$strawberry = new Strawberry("Strawberry", "red");  // OK. __construct() is public
$strawberry->message(); // OK. message() is public
$strawberry->intro(); // ERROR. intro() is protected
 ?>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
<?phpclass Fruit {  public 
    $name;  public $color;  public 
    function __construct($name, $color) {    $this->name = $name;    $this->color = $color;
      }  
    protected function intro() {    echo "The fruit is {$this->name} 
    and the color is {$this->color}.";
      }}class 
    Strawberry extends Fruit {  public 
    function message() {    echo "Am I a fruit or a 
    berry? ";
      }}// Try to call all three methods from outside class$strawberry = new Strawberry("Strawberry", "red");  
    // OK. __construct() is public$strawberry->message(); // OK. message() 
    is public$strawberry->intro(); // ERROR. intro() 
    is protected
    ?>

"The fruit is {$this->name} 
    and the color is {$this->color}."

"Am I a fruit or a 
    berry? "
// Try to call all three methods from outside class

content.text: In the example above we see that if we try to call a protected method (intro()) from outside the class, we will receive an error. public methods will work fine!
content.html: In the example above we see that if we try to call a protected method (intro()) from outside the class, we will receive an error. public methods will work fine!

content.text: Let's look at another example:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<?phpclass Fruit {  public $name;  public 
    $color;  public function __construct($name, $color) {    
    $this->name = $name;    $this->color = $color;   
    }  protected function intro() {    echo "The 
    fruit is {$this->name} and the color is {$this->color}.";   }}
    class Strawberry extends Fruit {  public function message() {    
    echo "Am I a fruit or a berry? ";    // Call protected 
    method from within derived class - OK    $this -> 
    intro();  }}
    $strawberry = new Strawberry("Strawberry", "red"); // OK. __construct() is 
    public$strawberry->message(); // OK. message() is 
    public and it calls intro() (which is protected) from within the 
    derived class?>

"The 
    fruit is {$this->name} and the color is {$this->color}."
"Am I a fruit or a berry? "

// Call protected 
    method from within derived class - OK

echo "Am I a fruit or a berry? ";    // Call protected
method from within derived class - OK    $this ->
intro();  }}

public$strawberry->message(); // OK. message() is

 echo "Am I a fruit or a berry? ";    // Call protected

content.code_html:
<?php
class Fruit {
  public $name;
  public $color;
  public function __construct($name, $color) {
    $this->name = $name;
    $this->color = $color;
  }
  protected function intro() {
    echo "The fruit is {$this->name} and the color is {$this->color}.";
  }
}

class Strawberry extends Fruit {
  public function message() {
    echo "Am I a fruit or a berry? ";
    // Call protected method from within derived class - OK
    $this -> intro();
  }
}

$strawberry = new Strawberry("Strawberry", "red"); // OK. __construct() is public
$strawberry->message(); // OK. message() is public and it calls intro() (which is protected) from within the derived class
?>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
<?phpclass Fruit {  public $name;  public 
    $color;  public function __construct($name, $color) {    
    $this->name = $name;    $this->color = $color;   
    }  protected function intro() {    echo "The 
    fruit is {$this->name} and the color is {$this->color}.";   }}
    class Strawberry extends Fruit {  public function message() {    
    echo "Am I a fruit or a berry? ";    // Call protected 
    method from within derived class - OK    $this -> 
    intro();  }}
    $strawberry = new Strawberry("Strawberry", "red"); // OK. __construct() is 
    public$strawberry->message(); // OK. message() is 
    public and it calls intro() (which is protected) from within the 
    derived class?>

"The 
    fruit is {$this->name} and the color is {$this->color}."
"Am I a fruit or a berry? "

// Call protected 
    method from within derived class - OK

content.text: In the example above we see that all works fine! It is because we call the protected method (intro()) from inside the derived class.
content.html: In the example above we see that all works fine! It is because we call the protected method (intro()) from inside the derived class.

content.text: PHP - Overriding Inherited Methods
Inherited methods can be overridden by redefining the methods (use the same name) in the child class.
content.html: Inherited methods can be overridden by redefining the methods (use the same name) in the child class.

content.text: Look at the example below. The __construct() and intro() methods in the child class (Strawberry) will override the __construct() and intro() methods in the parent class (Fruit):
content.html: Look at the example below. The __construct() and intro() methods in the child class (Strawberry) will override the __construct() and intro() methods in the parent class (Fruit):

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<?phpclass Fruit {  public 
    $name;  public $color;  public 
    function __construct($name, $color) {    $this->name = $name;    $this->color = $color;
      }  
    public function intro() {    echo "The fruit is {$this->name} 
    and the color is {$this->color}.";
      }}class 
    Strawberry extends Fruit {  public $weight;  public 
    function __construct($name, $color, $weight) {    $this->name = $name;    $this->color = $color;    $this->weight = $weight;
      }  
    public function intro() {    echo "The fruit is {$this->name}, the color is {$this->color}, 
    and the weight is {$this->weight} gram.";
      }}$strawberry = new Strawberry("Strawberry", "red", 
    50);$strawberry->intro();?>

"The fruit is {$this->name} 
    and the color is {$this->color}."

"The fruit is {$this->name}, the color is {$this->color}, 
    and the weight is {$this->weight} gram."

$name;  public $color;  public
function __construct($name, $color) {    $this->name = $name;    $this->color = $color;
}
public function intro() {    echo "The fruit is {$this->name}
and the color is {$this->color}.";
}}class
Strawberry extends Fruit {  public $weight;  public
function __construct($name, $color, $weight) {    $this->name = $name;    $this->color = $color;    $this->weight = $weight;
}
public function intro() {    echo "The fruit is {$this->name}, the color is {$this->color},
and the weight is {$this->weight} gram.";
}}$strawberry = new Strawberry("Strawberry", "red",
50);$strawberry->intro();?>

content.code_html:
<?php
class Fruit {
  public $name;
  public $color;
  public function __construct($name, $color) {
    $this->name = $name;
    $this->color = $color;
  }
  public function intro() {
    echo "The fruit is {$this->name} and the color is {$this->color}.";
  }
}

class Strawberry extends Fruit {
  public $weight;
  public function __construct($name, $color, $weight) {
    $this->name = $name;
    $this->color = $color;
    $this->weight = $weight;
  }
  public function intro() {
    echo "The fruit is {$this->name}, the color is {$this->color}, and the weight is {$this->weight} gram.";
  }
}

$strawberry = new Strawberry("Strawberry", "red", 50);
$strawberry->intro();
?>

content.text: PHP - The final Keyword
The final keyword can be used to prevent class inheritance or to prevent method overriding.
content.html: The final keyword can be used to prevent class inheritance or to prevent method overriding.

content.text: The following example shows how to prevent class inheritance:
content.html: The following example shows how to prevent class inheritance:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<?phpfinal class Fruit {  // some code }// 
    will result in errorclass 
    Strawberry extends Fruit {  // some code}?>

content.code:
<?phpfinal class Fruit {  // some code }// 
will result in errorclass
Strawberry extends Fruit {  // some code}?>

syntax_highlighting.text:
<?phpfinal class Fruit {  // some code }// 
    will result in errorclass 
    Strawberry extends Fruit {  // some code}?>

content.code_html:
<?php
final class Fruit {
  // some code
}

// will result in error
class Strawberry extends Fruit {
  // some code
}
?>

syntax_highlighting_data.text:
<?phpfinal class Fruit {  // some code }// 
    will result in errorclass 
    Strawberry extends Fruit {  // some code}?>

content.text: The following example shows how to prevent method overriding:
content.html: The following example shows how to prevent method overriding:

syntaxHighlighting.text:
<?phpclass Fruit {  
    final public function intro() {    // some code  }}class 
    Strawberry extends Fruit {  // 
    will result in error  
    public function intro() {    // some code  }}?>
